headline.main: Male Breakthrough in Sports

key_0.snippet: This sentence, buried in the middle of the article ''Cheerleading Changes as Boys Join Sidelines'' on May 2, says it all: ''At the schools where the cheerleaders were interviewed, the squad still only went out to cheer for major boys' sports.''   ...
key_0.lead_paragraph: This sentence, buried in the middle of the article ''Cheerleading Changes as Boys Join Sidelines'' on May 2, says it all: ''At the schools where the cheerleaders were interviewed, the squad still only went out to cheer for major boys' sports.'' No matter how many boys sign up, until cheerleading squads are equally assigned to girls' sports as well, cheerleading (and its still predominantly female members) will continue to be viewed as serving the traditionally dominant male athletic culture in these schools. JENNY GEER Larchmont

key_0.snippet: A VERY BRUNDAGE is a brave man of such lofty principles that he deems compromise or expediency a coward's cloak. No sooner had the millionaire ex-decathlon champion been elected president of the International Olympic Committee last July, the first...
key_0.lead_paragraph: A VERY BRUNDAGE is a brave man of such lofty principles that he deems compromise or expediency a coward's cloak. No sooner had the millionaire ex-decathlon champion been elected president of the International Olympic Committee last July, the first American ever so honored, than he flailed away with his usual vigor at the evils threatening the Olympic movement. He pointed one accusing finger at the curse of "gigantism."

headline.main: Sports of The Times; More Deadly Than the Male

key_0.snippet: HIS credentials to coach women's professional basketball were unassailable, though Van Chancellor admits his original intentions were not altogether pure.    It was during the mid-1960's when Chancellor, teaching math and coaching boys' basketball...
key_0.lead_paragraph: HIS credentials to coach women's professional basketball were unassailable, though Van Chancellor admits his original intentions were not altogether pure. It was during the mid-1960's when Chancellor, teaching math and coaching boys' basketball in Horn Lake, Miss., went to the principal one day and said he needed a study hall break. ''There weren't too many math teachers in Mississippi in those days,'' the coach of the Houston Comets drawled recently on the phone. ''They told me they also needed a coach for the girls' team. If I took it over, I'd be able to get out of two classes a day.''

key_0.snippet: IN basketball, the answer to Sigmund Freud's long-discussed question -- what do women want? -- is not very complicated. Just ask Stephanie Ready.    She wants, generally, what guys want: a good job, respect, the chance to succeed or fail on her me...
key_0.lead_paragraph: IN basketball, the answer to Sigmund Freud's long-discussed question -- what do women want? -- is not very complicated. Just ask Stephanie Ready. She wants, generally, what guys want: a good job, respect, the chance to succeed or fail on her merits, in a passion of her choosing, and with no glass rafters. She wants to win and, as a coach, to develop good players along the way.

CONFRONTING STEREOTYPES IN YONKERS FOOTBALL SUIT

byline.original: By VIRGINIA KNAPLUND; Virginia Knaplund, a White Plains attorney, is one of a group of volunteer lawyers who litigate constitutional issues on behalf of the Westchester Civil Liberties Union. ''Why would a girl want to play football?'' ''Girls will get injured because they're smaller and weaker than boys.''   ''If you let girls play on boys' teams, you'll have to let boys play on girls' teams and the boys will dominate the sport.''   These are the stereotypes embodied in the recently nullified New York State regulation that prohibited all girls in all public high schools in New York from trying out for all contact sports. Like most stereotypes, they are true for some people and not for others.   When the Westchester Chapter of the New York Civil Liberties Union asked me to challenge this regulation in court, I was not aware of its existence. An avid football fan, I grew up in a football family, and later watched my son play in countless elementary, junior high and high school games. But the idea of girls playing football with boys had not occurred to me.   Consequently, when Jacqueline Lantz and her parents sought my help in fighting the barrier that prevented her from trying out for junior varsity football at Lincoln High School in Yonkers, I was forced to confront the stereotypes that I, and most other New Yorkers, had never had occasion to consider.   The first question was easy: why would a girl want to play football? The answer came quickly: for the same reasons that a boy wants to play. Football is fun and challenging; it develops teamwork, strength of character, competitive instincts and leadership qualities; it provides camaraderie with teammates and recognition and admiration from classmates; it helps with admission and scholarships to college; and, in some cases, it leads to a lucrative career in professional football.   Not surprisingly, these are rewards that appealed to Jacqueline Lantz, and convinced her that the long months of physical training and risk of injury associated with football were worth enduring. Her parents were supportive of her desire to be the best she could be, while never minimizing the risks of injury faced by all those who engage in contact sports.   A Hollywood casting director could not have sent me a more ideal plaintiff for a lawsuit challenging out-moded ideas about females in our society. Jacqueline is bright, athletic and articulate, with a gentle manner that hides an indomitable spirit. When she was first prevented from trying out for the junior varsity squad, she continued fighting because she ''just wanted to play football.'' But after a year and a half of being told that her only disqualification was being a girl, her desire to play fused with a determination to remove the state rule that predetermined that every girl is physically inferior to every boy.   Yonkers coaches and school officials, many of whom were sympathetic to Jacqueline's desire to play, were bound by the state rule, so it was necessary to sue the State Commissioner of Education and the Board of Regents, who are jointly responsible for enacting and enforcing rules governing the public schools, as well as the Yonkers School Board and the New York State Public High School Athletic Association.   We asked the U.S. District Court to strike down the regulation as unconstitutional because it denied girls equal treatment under the law, as guaranteed by the 14th Amendment of the United States Constitution.   Laws that discriminate on the basis of sex are permitted under the Constitution only if they accomplish a valid governmental objective in a way reasonably calculated to further that interest. This law, we believed, neither furthered an important government interest or treated girls in a fair and reasonable way.   At trial the issues were sharply defined. The Government defendants offered expert testimony to prove a fact we readily conceded: the average girl is smaller, weaker and slower than the average boy. This disparity, they argued, makes the average girl more prone to injury than the average boy, and justifies prohibiting all girls, no matter how big, strong and fast, from qualifying to play football against boys. Safety, they said, is an important governmental objective that permits sex discrimination, and the regulation is reasonable because it prevents all girls from risking injury.   We argued that safety was not the only governmental objective in athletics. If it were, boys would not be permitted to play football, since there is a wide range in size, strength, speed, and consequent risk of injury among boys who play, as well. We pointed out that every court that has considered this issue has ruled that the Government cannot prohibit female competition in mixed football competition, because such participation fosters athletic opportunities for girls and redresses past discrimination against girls in sports. The most reasonable and safe way to accomplish these goals, the courts have said, is by considering girls as individuals, not as averages.   The Supreme Court has gradually struck down broad generalizations about females that do not hold true for all members of the sex. In these days when the Harlem Globetrotters have a woman player and a team of female climbers makes an assault on Mount Everest, it is hard to believe that in the recent past we have had laws to ''protect'' women because they were considered too delicate to practice law, work at night, tend bar, drive trucks, fight fires or engage in many other traditionally male activities.   The government also argued that permitting girls' participation on boys' teams would require reciprocal permission for boys to play on girls' teams. They feared that this could lead to dominance by boys and an actual decrease in girls' participation. This argument has been uniformly rejected by appellate courts around the country because past discrimination against females in sports justifies a prohibition of boys' playing on girls' teams - in order to promote equality of opportunity. The application of this concept of affirmative action to women is now firmly established by the Supreme Court.   In addition, the Government's argument that permitting girls to participate in contact sports with boys would decrease overall participation by girls in athletics was contradicted by the defendants' own witnesses. They testified that in the years since girls had been allowed to compete against boys in other sports such as baseball, tennis and soccer, the number of girls involved in athletics had increased dramatically.   After considering these arguments and facts, Judge Louis Stanton ruled that a safety regulation that prevents all girls, even those who could play safely, from trying out for football, while permitting all boys, even those who could not play safely, was too broad to be reasonably related to its objective. He found that it was unfair to prohibit those girls who were strong and fit enough to play, merely because the average girl was not as fit as the average boy.   Judge Stanton ordered that Jacqueline Lantz be given the same chance as her male teammates to display her abilities, and declared that the regulation that deprived her of her right to try out on an equal basis with boys was unconstitutional. In doing so, he ruled that Jacqueline Lantz, and every other girl in a New York State public high school, must be treated as an individual and not as an average.   Jacqueline's victory was not only a victory for high school girls. An additional benefit is that the publicity surrounding her suit has focused attention on the safety of high school football as presently regulated by the State Education Commission. The commission's experts testified to the inordinate risk of injury that accompanies football played by students of widely disparate weight, height and maturity, and the Government's evidence showed that this disparity is the greatest among boys. If this lawsuit causes the Regents and the commissioner to devise football safety regulations based on classifications by size (such as presently exist in boxing and wrestling) Jacqueline's victory will make football safer for all those who play.   Jacqueline is now on the junior varsity squad at Lincoln High School. Her coach says she's not in condition to engage in contact scrimmage and play, largely because she missed the first seven weeks of practice. But Jacqueline respects his right and duty to make that judgment. She's just happy to be there every day, and proud to be one of the team.   Virginia Knaplund, a White Plains attorney, is one of a group of volunteer lawyers who litigate constitutional issues on behalf of the Westchester Civil Liberties Union

Rhoden describes how the male-dominated ethic of sports can lead to the treatment of women as objects and to the tolerance of serious offenses such as rape ("No Lesson May Come in Tyson Verdict," The Times, Feb. 12). While I welcome an article on this subject, I wonder why Rhoden chose to quote only men. Are we to infer that only men can be experts on male domination?

key_4.lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee agreed to adopt rules for dealing with cases of female athletes who have excessive levels of male hormones. Arne Ljungqvist, the I.O.C. medical commission chairman, said the committee would enact rules for determining the eligibility of women with hyperandrogenism, which involves overproduction of male sex hormones, in time for the 2012 London Games.

headline.main: Sex-Verification Rules Planned

key_4.snippet: Research showing a lag in the academic performance of Division III athletes has caught the N.C.A.A.'s attention. A review of first-year academic records at 88 of the division's most selective universities by the College Sports Project showed that ...
key_4.lead_paragraph: Research showing a lag in the academic performance of Division III athletes has caught the N.C.A.A.'s attention. A review of first-year academic records at 88 of the division's most selective universities by the College Sports Project showed that male athletes on average had poorer grades than their counterparts in the overall student body. The gap was larger for recruited male athletes. In response, the N.C.A.A. is considering tracking graduation rates and other measures of academic performance. Until now, that task has been left up to individual universities in Division III.

headline.main: Concern For Division III
Hull of Black Hawks Voted Top Male Athlete in Canada

key_5.abstract: Wave of coaches embroiled in child sexual abuse scandals is garnering a closer look at the link between coaching and molestation; experts say the sports environment has all the ingredients to facilitate misconduct: coaches have close relationships with children and unsupervised access to them, while holding a position of trust and authority that can often keep children from reporting abuses.

key_5.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: It is ironic that the erosion of Title IX's socially salubrious requirements of gender equity in college sports was initiated by a lawsuit filed by the college wrestling coaches' association. Considering America's curious fascination with female wrestling, as evidenced by the recent number of pop culture references to this sport, one would think that instead of ending male programs, colleges and universities would advance female wrestling as a revenue producer that would rival football and basketball.

key_7.snippet: To the Sports Editor:    Three cheers for the article on Billy Bean and the problem of homophobia in male team sports (''A Major League Player's Life of Isolation and Secret Fear,'' The Times, Sept. 6).    I have experience being openly gay in two...
key_7.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: Three cheers for the article on Billy Bean and the problem of homophobia in male team sports (''A Major League Player's Life of Isolation and Secret Fear,'' The Times, Sept. 6). I have experience being openly gay in two worlds with strong traditions of hyper-masculinity and homophobia: Wall Street and heavy metal rock music. I've encountered plenty of enemies, but also plenty of intense support. The myth that all masculine straight men are homophobic has to be exploded.
key_7.abstract: William Dunmyer letter lauds September 6 article on Billy Bean and problem of homophobia in male team sports; written transcript and audio discussion of September 9 New York Times forum is available on Times' Web site (S)

headline.main: Debunking a Myth Of Homophobia

key_8.snippet: To the Sports Editor:    On every sports page there are tales of great athletes and the lengths taken for those athletes to achieve their goals. The majority of these pages are filled with male athletes and although there are women represented, it...
key_8.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: On every sports page there are tales of great athletes and the lengths taken for those athletes to achieve their goals. The majority of these pages are filled with male athletes and although there are women represented, it is not with the vigor that the men receive. Women also do great things, most recently the bobsled team that won Olympic gold, but do not receive as much attention. Female athletes should receive equal representation for their efforts. RACHEL A. JOHNSON Mesa, Ariz.
key_8.abstract: Letter to editor argues that female athletes, for example US Olympic female bobsled team, receive less attention and coverage from media than male athletes (M)

headline.main: Women Deserve Better

key_8.snippet: To the Sports Editor:  Teresa H. Skehan (Mailbox, Aug. 24) would like to see the use of a gender correct ''woman to woman'' to describe basketball in the Women's National Basketball Association, using such ''power gently and persistently toward a ...
key_8.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: Teresa H. Skehan (Mailbox, Aug. 24) would like to see the use of a gender correct ''woman to woman'' to describe basketball in the Women's National Basketball Association, using such ''power gently and persistently toward a more equal society.'' How absurd! Simply adopt a genderless phrase, the way the National Football League male sports announcers have done for years, more accurately describing a man-to-man defense for what it is -- one to one. GRADY THURMAN St. Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands
key_8.abstract: Grady Thurman letter comments on Teresa H Skehan's Aug 24 letter calling for 'gender correct' descriptions of play in Women's National Basketball Assn

headline.main: A Vote for 'One'

key_8.snippet: To the Sports Editor:    ''Another Male Coach Hired in W.N.B.A.'' (The Times, Dec. 8) was less a serious sports commentary than a piece of feel-good drivel. I presume the W.N.B.A.'s goal is not to be the type of quota-driven social laboratory that...
key_8.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: ''Another Male Coach Hired in W.N.B.A.'' (The Times, Dec. 8) was less a serious sports commentary than a piece of feel-good drivel. I presume the W.N.B.A.'s goal is not to be the type of quota-driven social laboratory that Harvey Araton seemingly desires, but to become profitable by offering the best quality entertainment possible. If the W.N.B.A. and its teams can do this by having all, none or some male coaches, I presume they will take the most advantageous course.
key_8.abstract: Edward S Hochman letter on Harvey Araton's Dec 8 article on concern over number of men being hired to coach teams in Women's National Basketball Association says Dec 8 article was less a serious sports commentary than piece of feel-good drivel (S)

key_9.snippet: To the Sports Editor:    Regarding ''Hoops, Hurt and Hoopla'' (The Times, Aug. 17): why did The Times think it was appropriate to include a photo of the Liberty forward Kym Hampton in the restroom doing her hair? According to the caption, Hampton ...
key_9.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: Regarding ''Hoops, Hurt and Hoopla'' (The Times, Aug. 17): why did The Times think it was appropriate to include a photo of the Liberty forward Kym Hampton in the restroom doing her hair? According to the caption, Hampton was preparing for a game. Did she not stretch, take practice shots and warm up in any way that would have provided you with a proper photo of a male athlete published in the sports section, and I am a longtime reader. Personal grooming does not seem to qualify as sports news. KAREN KOFFLER Kew Gardens, Queens
